docs.lead_paragraph: Bee writes: When I was young, my parents made me terrified of marijuana. They told me if I tried it, the next step was cocaine addiction. Now my parents are in their 60s, and they’re stoned every night on edibles. They once ate Skittles for dinner; it bums me out. Am I right to be concerned about how they’ve decided to live?

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Parents Who Get Into Edibles
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: Can you put it back in the toaster once there’s butter on it?
docs.snippet: Can you put it back in the toaster once there’s butter on it?
docs.lead_paragraph: Anna writes: My husband puts buttered toast back in the toaster to melt the butter. I think it’s dangerous to do that in a vertical toaster. He says that he has been doing this for years without issue.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Pre-Buttered Toast

docs.abstract: Should you put something in your mouth that has been in the toilet?
docs.snippet: Should you put something in your mouth that has been in the toilet?
docs.lead_paragraph: Hans writes: My friends Henning and Erin are getting married in July, and as a gift, I would like you to judge their crimes. Henning once dropped his toothbrush in the toilet and continued using it. Erin uses his toothbrush when she visits; he didn’t tell her. I ask the judge to order Henning to throw all toilet toothbrushes away, and order Erin to never use another’s toothbrush again.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Toilet Toothbrushes
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: Should the recipient be insulted? Grossed out? What if he’s from Vermont?
docs.snippet: Should the recipient be insulted? Grossed out? What if he’s from Vermont?
docs.lead_paragraph: Aaron writes: Over brunch, my mother offered me two sticks of my dad’s deodorant, one of which she described as “practically unused.” I refused the latter, a decision my mother described as germophobic. I strongly disagree. Who’s right?

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Gifting Used Deodorant
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: What do we owe to our local snapping turtles?
docs.snippet: What do we owe to our local snapping turtles?
docs.lead_paragraph: Alex writes: My parents’ yard abuts a protected marshland. I recently observed a snapping-turtle nest by a bird feeder at the yard’s edge. My research suggests the hatchlings will head to the marsh. I want to protect the nest. My father wants to destroy it: He’s concerned the turtles will antagonize the birds.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on the Dangers of Turtles
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: Should dinner guests be exposed to ... that?
docs.snippet: Should dinner guests be exposed to ... that?
docs.lead_paragraph: Katie writes: My husband and I have two Squatty Potty toilet stools: one for the upstairs bathroom and one downstairs. When we have guests over, my husband hides the downstairs one. I think we should leave it out.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on the Guest Bathroom Squatty Potty

docs.abstract: At what point can you steal candy that has been left on the counter?
docs.snippet: At what point can you steal candy that has been left on the counter?
docs.lead_paragraph: Emily writes: My husband, Neil, does not respect the rule (made by me) that if YOUR chocolate sits on the kitchen counter for three days, it automatically becomes MY chocolate.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Spousal Chocolate Theft
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman

docs.abstract: At least 103 pro-government forces and 96 civilians have been killed in Afghanistan so far this month.
docs.snippet: At least 103 pro-government forces and 96 civilians have been killed in Afghanistan so far this month.
docs.lead_paragraph: [Read the Afghan War Casualty Report from previous weeks.]

docs.abstract: The Republican operative transformed the most infamous gesture in American political history — from a symbol of defiance to a simple farce.
docs.snippet: The Republican operative transformed the most infamous gesture in American political history — from a symbol of defiance to a simple farce.
docs.lead_paragraph: History tends to repeat itself, but we aren’t always obligated to listen. Only rarely is the repetition meaningful, the echoing theme of a grand fugue. More often it is just compulsive, like a little brother antagonizing his sister or a tiny dog yapping at the wind.

docs.abstract: Should a husband miss his chance to become a Catan champion just because he’s expecting a child?
docs.snippet: Should a husband miss his chance to become a Catan champion just because he’s expecting a child?
docs.lead_paragraph: Karen writes: My husband and I are expecting a baby soon and moving to a new house either this weekend or next. My husband has qualified for the Catan U.S. Championship Tournament this weekend. My doctor said it would be O.K. for him to go because the baby is not likely to arrive. I want to support him, but I think we should move this weekend instead because we have a baby coming.

headline.main: Judge John Hodgman on Board Games and Babies
headline.print_headline: Bonus Advice From Judge John Hodgman
